BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often large wind slabs can be released easily or naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of snow will fall over a wide area. This applies in particular in the afternoon. Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow can be released naturally in all aspects and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. Many large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are possible. Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and in some cases endanger exposed transportation routes.
Below approximately 2000 m medium-sized to large moist and wet avalanches are possible.

The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 50 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 1600 m. A lot of snow will fall from midday over a wide area. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in the last two days in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at intermediate and high altitudes.
The new snow of last week is lying on a crust on sunny slopes. This snow is lying on soft layers on shady slopes and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Towards its base, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.

The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and great restraint.

The new snow of last week is lying on a crust on sunny slopes. This snow is lying on soft layers on shady slopes and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.

Over a wide area over a wide area 50 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 1600 m. A lot of snow will fall from midday over a wide area. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in the last two days in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at intermediate and high altitudes.

Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow require caution. Extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger is important.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of snow will fall over a wide area. Here the snowfall level will be approximately 1600 m.
Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow can be released naturally. This applies in particular above approximately 1800 m in all aspects. Many large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
Below approximately 2000 m medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large moist and wet avalanches are possible.

The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 30 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in the last two days.
The new snow of last week is lying on a crust on sunny slopes. This snow is lying on soft layers on shady slopes and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
The old snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow require caution. Extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger is important.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of snow will fall over a wide area. Here the snowfall level will be approximately 1600 m.
Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow can be released naturally. This applies in particular above approximately 1800 m in all aspects. Many large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
Below approximately 2000 m medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large moist and wet avalanches are possible.

The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 30 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in the last two days.
The new snow of last week is lying on a crust on sunny slopes. This snow is lying on soft layers on shady slopes and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
The old snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released easily or naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can still in isolated cases be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach large size. This applies especially above approximately 2400 m, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
Increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches until the temperature drops. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural moist avalanches are possible over a wide area.

The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 60 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 1800 m. The new snow has bonded well with the old snowpack in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2500 m. The new snow of last week is lying on a crust on sunny slopes.
The snowpack will become moist at low and intermediate altitudes. The old snowpack is largely stable.

In these regions up to 10 cm of snow will fall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as the precipitation becomes more intense. The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last two days adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above the tree line. Here they will increase in size additionally until Saturday. They can be released easily or naturally in all aspects.

During the day: The natural activity of avalanches will gradually increase. The avalanches can be released in the new snow and wind slab layers and reach large size in some cases. As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and in some places endanger exposed transportation routes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
25 to 40 cm of snow, and up to 60 cm in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. This applies in particular along the border with Switzerland.
Since Thursday the wind has been strong to storm force at times. The southerly wind has transported the new snow significantly.
Saturday: Above approximately 2000 m more snow will fall. This applies in particular in the afternoon. The rain will give rise in the afternoon to a loss of strength within the snowpack below approximately 2300 m.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Dry and moist avalanches are to be expected as the precipitation becomes more intense.
The avalanches can reach the valleys and in some places endanger transportation routes that are exposed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as the precipitation becomes more intense. The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last two days adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above the tree line. Here they will increase in size additionally until Saturday. They can be released easily or naturally in all aspects.

During the day: The natural activity of avalanches will gradually increase. The avalanches can be released in the new snow and wind slab layers and reach large size in some cases. As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and in some places endanger exposed transportation routes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
25 to 40 cm of snow, and up to 60 cm in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. This applies in particular along the border with Switzerland.
Since Thursday the wind has been strong to storm force at times. The southerly wind has transported the new snow significantly.
Saturday: Above approximately 2000 m more snow will fall. This applies in particular in the afternoon. The rain will give rise in the afternoon to a loss of strength within the snowpack below approximately 2300 m.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Dry and moist avalanches are to be expected as the precipitation becomes more intense.
The avalanches can reach the valleys and in some places endanger transportation routes that are exposed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the snowfall the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses. In these regions the avalanche danger will increase during the day to level 3 (considerable). New snow and wind slabs can in many places be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach large size in isolated cases. The more recent wind slabs will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
As the penetration by moisture increases more frequent medium-sized wet slab avalanches are possible below approximately 2000 m.

The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Above approximately 1600 m snow will fall over a wide area. As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days.
The new snow of last week is lying on a crust in particular on east to south to west facing aspects.
The old snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the snowfall the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses. In these regions the avalanche danger will increase during the day to level 3 (considerable). New snow and wind slabs can in many places be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach large size in isolated cases. The more recent wind slabs will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
As the penetration by moisture increases more frequent medium-sized wet slab avalanches are possible below approximately 2000 m.

The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Above approximately 1600 m snow will fall over a wide area. As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days.
The new snow of last week is lying on a crust in particular on east to south to west facing aspects.
The old snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as the precipitation becomes more intense. The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last two days adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above the tree line. Here they will increase in size additionally until Saturday. They can be released easily or naturally in all aspects. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is slightly greater.


During the day: The natural activity of avalanches will gradually increase. The avalanches can be released in the new snow and wind slab layers and reach quite a large size. As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, and up to 60 cm in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m, in particular along the border with Switzerland.
Since Thursday the wind has been strong at times. The southerly wind has transported the new snow significantly.
Saturday: Above approximately 2000 m more snow will fall. This applies in particular in the afternoon.
The rain will give rise in the afternoon to a loss of strength within the snowpack below approximately 2300 m.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Dry and moist avalanches are to be expected as the precipitation becomes more intense.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as the precipitation becomes more intense. The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last two days adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above the tree line. Here they will increase in size additionally until Saturday. They can be released easily or naturally in all aspects. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is slightly greater.


During the day: The natural activity of avalanches will gradually increase. The avalanches can be released in the new snow and wind slab layers and reach quite a large size. As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, and up to 60 cm in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m, in particular along the border with Switzerland.
Since Thursday the wind has been strong at times. The southerly wind has transported the new snow significantly.
Saturday: Above approximately 2000 m more snow will fall. This applies in particular in the afternoon.
The rain will give rise in the afternoon to a loss of strength within the snowpack below approximately 2300 m.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Dry and moist avalanches are to be expected as the precipitation becomes more intense.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A precarious avalanche situation will prevail. Significant increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, further wind slabs will form from the middle of the day in all aspects. These can be released easily or naturally. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above the tree line, and in areas close to the tree line. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. In some cases avalanches are large.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the heavy rain more frequent moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected from midday, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on extremely steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.

Backcountry touring calls for very extensive experience and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall from midday. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A critical avalanche situation will be encountered over a wide area. 10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be an increase in the avalanche danger within the current danger level. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. Below approximately 2600 m: Wet and gliding snow require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A precarious avalanche situation will prevail. Significant increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, further wind slabs will form from the middle of the day in all aspects. These can be released easily or naturally. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above the tree line, and in areas close to the tree line. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. In some cases avalanches are large.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the heavy rain more frequent moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected from midday, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on extremely steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.

Backcountry touring calls for very extensive experience and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall from midday. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A critical avalanche situation will be encountered over a wide area. 10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be an increase in the avalanche danger within the current danger level. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. Below approximately 2600 m: Wet and gliding snow require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from southerly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as above the tree line. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. As a consequence of warming during the day more frequent moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. Mostly small dry and moist avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of the rain. On steep grassy slopes more medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind was strong to storm force at times. Over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow, and up to 70 cm in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 2000 m. The wind was strong. In places that are protected from the wind wind slabs formed. These are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in all aspects above the tree line. The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In the afternoon as a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be an increase in the avalanche danger within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence at intermediate and high altitudes. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
The rain will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Gradual increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects.
Avalanches can be released, even by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In the last few days wind slabs formed. The new snow and wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. The weather conditions will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area precipitation. The wind will be moderate to strong.
In all aspects further wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, further wind slabs will form from the middle of the day in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. These can be released easily. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the rain individual moist loose snow slides are to be expected from midday. This applies in particular on extremely steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.

Backcountry touring calls for experience and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall from midday. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on west to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Wind slabs represent the main danger. Below approximately 2600 m: Wet and gliding snow require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, further wind slabs will form from the middle of the day in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. These can be released easily. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the rain individual moist loose snow slides are to be expected from midday. This applies in particular on extremely steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.

Backcountry touring calls for experience and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall from midday. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on west to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Wind slabs represent the main danger. Below approximately 2600 m: Wet and gliding snow require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow and in particular the wind slabs formed during the snowfall can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible, in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
In all aspects and at intermediate and high altitudes more frequent medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the precipitation becomes more intense.
Caution is to be exercised on steep grassy slopes, as well as at the base of rock walls in particular below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 1500 m. The wind was strong to storm force at times. In places that are protected from the wind sometimes large wind slabs formed. These are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in all aspects above the tree line.
Over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday above approximately 2000 m. The wind slabs of the last few days will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.
The rain will give rise to rapid moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Sunday above approximately 1800 m. New snow and wind slabs require caution. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain easily released wind slabs will form. Skiers can release avalanches very easily, including large ones. Remotely triggered and natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular on steep slopes. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, further wind slabs will form from the middle of the day in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. These can be released easily. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

On steep grassy slopes small to medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the rain individual moist loose snow slides are to be expected from midday. This applies in particular on extremely steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.

Backcountry touring calls for experience and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall from midday. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on west to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. High altitudes: Wind slabs represent the main danger. Below approximately 2600 m: Wet and gliding snow require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, further wind slabs will form from the middle of the day in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. These can be released easily. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

On steep grassy slopes small to medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the rain individual moist loose snow slides are to be expected from midday. This applies in particular on extremely steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.

Backcountry touring calls for experience and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall from midday. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on west to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. High altitudes: Wind slabs represent the main danger. Below approximately 2600 m: Wet and gliding snow require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day. In addition the wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day more moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected. On very steep grassy slopes more gliding avalanches are possible. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, above approximately 2200 m. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Sometimes avalanches are medium-sized.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 15 to 40 cm of snow has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 1500 m. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack. The wind was moderate to strong. In the vicinity of peaks wind slabs formed.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As the day progresses as a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be an increase in the avalanche danger within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of the precipitation medium-sized wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 1700 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are very rare and are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally wet all the way through.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Mostly these are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 1900 m. In gullies and bowls a sometimes precarious avalanche situation will be encountered in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m hardly any snow is lying. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. As a consequence of the solar radiation, the likelihood of wet snow slides and avalanches being released will increase. The avalanche prone locations for moist avalanches are to be found especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and on steep slopes above approximately 1900 m.
